I have made decisions to quit smoking several times and I always failed but the last time I made a decision with my strong will and I kept various reasons and benefits to quit which includes my health, family, friends, career etc. At night it was tough to control and sleep without but I didn't lose faith but it was even tougher than I thought it would be when I woke up in the morning. I couldn't resist, so I went for the cigarette, I was about to fire it but before that I texted my friend about it. He called me, texted me back, and did his best for me to not smoke that time. Actually the crave for smoke that time was high because I had just gotten up and the brain wasn't fully functional to give a thought about what I decided yesterday with full confidence.
After that morning, the urge to smoke kept decreasing and I'm happy for it. This was all possible because I kept my faith and trust because I knew it would be worth everything. Right now I'm on my 11th or 12th day and I believe a much better life is on its way.

I smoked from 14 to 35 years old, in the last years I smoked an average of 30 cigarettes a day (1 pack and a half).
I gave my life to Jesus, and I felt the need not to smoke or consume alcohol anymore, with the alcoholic drink it was overnight, I threw away what I had of beer and cachaça at home... !
I agreed with my wife to try to smoke the least amount of cigarettes I could in one day so with a lot of effort on my part I smoked 12 cigarettes, for one week she gave me 12 cigarettes every day for me to consume, the other week it was 11 cigarettes a day day, the other 10... and each week it decreased by 1 per day.
everything was going well, until it reached 4 cigarettes... I started stealing cigarettes from her, and ended up smoking 7, 8 cigarettes a day. until one day that during a prayer I was sincere to God, and said that I couldn't stop smoking and that I didn't really have the strength and that I really wanted to and asked God to help me and take the pleasure of smoking from me...
One day inside the church during a preaching that a pastor was doing, I heard a voice speaking in my ear clearly; - "So far I've let you try, to show that you're not capable. From today you don't smoke because I don't want to!
I was so scared that when my wife told me what I had heard, she saw in me a frightened and admired person, who started to cry because she saw that I was not delirious.
Upon leaving the church my car had been broken into and my documents and my wife's documents had been stolen, along with the vehicle's sound. But I knew that if I got over that nervousness and anger I felt at seeing my car like that I wouldn't smoke anymore (it was like a test to confirm my convictions in the voice I heard).
I called my wife and we went home , I took everything I had connected to tobacco ( tobacco , paper , lighter , matches , cigarette pack ....) I put it on a piece of paper and rolled it up we went to the street, and on a sidewalk I threw alcohol and I prayed to God; - Lord, trusting the voice I heard today I know that I will no longer feel like smoking, in Jesus name I set fire to all these elements linked to cigarettes!
And by the honor and glory of God I was freed, in the name of Jesus!

I used to vape high miligram nicotine pods for 4 years 2017 through 2021. I decided to quit in November of 2021 and ever since I stopped getting out of breath so easily when carrying groceries. Ironically enough afterwards I smoked cigs for a couple of months but I quit that as well.

Obviously the best thing for your lungs are oxygen, and while I am on the side of smoking being worse than vapor, there are serious side effects from long term vaping. Aside from the improved respiratory system, another thing that motivated my quitting was realizing the baffling amount of nicotine in those pods (Juul, relx, and the like), that I used to use so frequently. Practically 24/7 in fact.

After researching and even doing more or less correct calculations using a formula I found once on the relx site, I have concluded that each pod contained way more nicotine than a standard full flavored cigarette (like marlboro red for example). Reds are already high in nicotine in the American market, so I'd say those pods are probably 5-10 times that compared to a pack of reds. Also each puff or two from a pod contained probably the same amount of nicotine from one marlboro red cigarette, and each puff or two probably contained multiple light cigarettes. I say "probably" because I don't know the exact numbers (and I always hated math). Nevertheless I believe I am in the correct ballpark.

Don't start smoking and don't start vaping. The only tobacco I would consume now would be the occasional cigar, because I fully believe there is a difference between smoking tobacco for the nicotine, and smoking tobacco for the flavors. True cigars are always higher quality than any cigarette tobacco.

If you're reading this and you want to quit vaping and smoking cigarettes I would highly recommend looking into snus. Real swedish snus, not that camel snus you saw at 7/11.

Thanks for reading my summed journey through vaping.

I listened to this type of information before my last cigarette which was April 2014. after 28 years of being a smoker,
Most of the information like this only applies to a chain smoker.
My experience was quite different..
It is important to note, I was at a point where I just didn't want to smoke any more, there were no reasons or pressure to not smoke, I just didn't want to smoke any more. Which is why it was so easy for me to do. I feel most people are pleasured into stopping for various reasons and they resent it so it because hard as they don't really want to do it.
My experience was..
No change in HR or BP they were normal (BP 130/70, HR Resting about 45 and under heavy cardio I could drive it to 200, but still have a 100 beat recovery in 30 seconds) while a smoker and never changed after.
After about 2 days I had loads more energy due to an excess amount of red blood cells which were no longer carrying carbon monoxide.
That was until they all died after about 30 days as they were no longer needed.
Cravings didn't happen at all, I put the last cigarette out and never thought about them again.
The ONLY significant change I could see was the nail on my right index finger was no longer yellow.

Side Note,
I have always been a keen cyclist and ALL of my PB times up hills were achieved as a smoker, since the last cigarette I have had many more attempts at the same hills and never been able to manage my time achieved as a smoker.
WTF I hear you say..
It's quite simple, you smoke your red blood cells get filled with carbon monoxide, so your body over compensates by producing more to keep oxygen sats in check. You stop smoking, the carbon monoxide drops, the body kills off the excess red blood cells after about 30 days and you are left will overall LESS red blood cells for carrying oxygen than you had as a smoker. My VO2 Max also dropped a little after stopping smoking.
I am certain if I had made the attempts between the 3 and 30 days after the last cigarette I would have done better, but I didn't get the chance

I do have to add I could not afford to smoke today with the price of cigarettes, or in my case it was rolling tobacco.

I quit cold turkey at the start of the day pandemic. I figured being on lockdown was as good a time as any. For me being a bartender and working in the restaurant industry, smoking after a dinner rush was a normal thing. What helped me stay on the path was I began working out, particularly running. I set goals for myself, short term and long term and took it one day at a time. Long term, which was especially true for a lot of people during the height of the pandemic, was to be stronger mentally and physically. Short I wanted to participate in a 5k marathon. As soon as I started seeing results, it was extra motivation to stay on the path. That was the  difference between the other time I had tried quitting and this time around. My body looked better than it ever had, and I could breathe clearer for the first time in almost 15 years, and the last thing I wanted to do was reverse all the progress I made. Those first few weeks were a challenge. But eventually the thoughts of wanting to smoke a cigarette begin to fade away with every passing day. In the beginning the thought of smoking a cigarette disgusted me. Now when I smell someone smoking a cigarette it does nothing for me, and that’s the way I like it :)

I'd sleep with the vape in my hand, ready to go in case I woke up in the night. 2 weeks ago I decided to drop nicotine altogether, and wow. It's only been 14 days, and the physical benefit is already noticeable and tremendous.
I love not waking up with headaches anymore.

You forgot to talk about what happens if a person stops smoking and experiences Acute Nicotine Withdrawal. The body can go into one of three responses and this is sometime seen in the ICU when admitted patients are asked to quit nicotine: Hyperactive, Hypoactive, or Mixed Delirium.

Delirium can be a very dangerous illness that lasts upwards of 3 months after a person has been smoking. That's ironically the same amount of time that it takes dopamine levels to stabilize in the altered brain. People with Delirium can experience permanent brain damage, cognitive decline and even need institutionalization because of how their body has had to stop using Nicotine.

Sadly, I wanted to quit "cold turkey" after smoking a pack and a half per day. I made it 46 hours before Delirium onset but now I will have to watch out for how much irreversible damage has been done to my brain. I'm sitting at four days now with my doctor giving me advice over the phone. I know that I cannot stay awake for more than 3 hours at a time. I sleep/nap for 2 hours but my brain tells me that I've been out for 8 hours. Pretty much list off the side effects of Delirium and I have them. I'm afraid of having to need life-long assistance now and not being independent ever again.

I have been smoking since I was 12, im 21 now and have quit smoking for a month now after being really addicted and thought I could never quit. I actually enjoyed seeing and noticing the side effects on my body. I was my own lab rat. It was hard at times, like after a meal or with coffee but as soon as some time passes and you don't smoke at these times the rest is easy. Doing activities and exercising helps the time you usually spent smoking to pass and sets the mind to forget about smoking making you want to get better and healthier allong the way. Been a pack a day smoker for approximately 16 years (I’m 35) and I’m currently on day 3 quitting cold turkey. 2 things that have helped me get through the first few days…
1) Regular chewing gum. I chew on gum CONSTANTLY to keep my mouth busy, and it REALLY helps.
2) I constantly remind myself (especially when getting a strong craving) that cigarettes literally do nothing for me, and smoking one isn’t going to change the way I feel. I know that sounds simple, but it really helps me push past each craving mentally….. telling myself (often out loud) that there is NO POINT in doing it!

I went abroad and used this change of surroundings to quit a few months ago. It really helps not to have the places that you associate with smoking. I had an depressive episode afterwards and I considered starting again for the sake of feeling fine. But I managed to find other ways of calming me down - gum, writing, yoga, breathing combining that with an app who counts the money I saved (Flamy). And I'm proud.
Actually I can concentrate way better now and I'm disgusted when I smell smoke now. I can't imagine that I smelled like that for years. Tbh it wasn't my first try of quitting, but I still think trying and failing is still better than happily poison yourself. You got that guys!

What motivated me to quit was Working out/sports and Saving Money, only way I could quit was going cold Turkey, my advise is somehow resist smoking for two weeks, after that I lost all cravings, eventually the thought of having a smoke will leave ur mind like it didnt exist.
1. Just dont make the mistake later in a couple of months down the lane (at a party with friends or a club) thinking i can stop my self later if i just take 1 smoke now, it goes downhill from there, I have relapsed like this thinking i can do the same thing of going cold turkey again, but its not worth it as it took me another year.
2. A good diet, lots of water & exercise can help make those two weeks bearable, the cravings (during those two weeks) usually hit when your bored/breaks/freetime, so try to keep yourself occupied doing something....anything
3. Nicotine patches didnt do shit for me (I feel it just makes you continue craving Nicotine hence cold turkey is best)
4. Usually people who are attached to smoking have something with it on the side, like to the bathroom while taking a dump, with your coffee, with alcohol etc, so try avoid these cravings especially at these moments during the 2 weeks phase
Best of luck to the PPL, who r trying to quit smoking 🚬

When I left the service my income took a big drop and we struggled to make ends meet, then the government increased the tax on cigaretes and I decided that I was not going to pay more tax. That was the last pack I smoked more than 50 years ago.  The hard times came in 3s, three hourd, three days, three weeks etc.  After a while it was too difficult to lose face and go back to smoking. I decided to smoke my last cigarette on the 13th September 2021, it has been a daily habit that started in 1985. I tried to quit many times but I just considered myself too feeble to carry it through. Of course being a drinker too, I decided (whilst drunk) to try one whilst in a smoky bar on the 17th. That rush of carbon monoxide, that disgusting tingling sensation you get when you smoke your first cigarette in three days came to me, the dizziness that the carbon monoxide replacing the oxygen in your blood gives you was a far worse sensation than any craving sensation that I had in the days before that, smoking really is poison. I have a vape with nicotine as a go to, but I didn't use it today, the pangs are getting less and less. 17th September was my last cigarette, I never want that nauseous sensation to happen again.

I started smoking at age 13 and smoked about a pack a day until I was 21 years old. From there, I started vaping with the purpose of quitting smoking and it worked so well. What I thought would be my last cigarette really was my last cigarette. Last year at the beginning of the pandemic, during when quarantine first started, I ended up losing my vape. I wasn't really able to leave my house to go out and get a new one, so I never did. What was an accident actually became how I ended up quitting nicotine altogether. I just never ended up buying a new vape and as each day went by, it got easier and easier to live without nicotine, until now where I can do things like step outside and not immediately want to smoke or vape, or eat a meal and not crave nicotine after eating. The freedom of finally being unchained from the most addictive substance I've ever had the displeasure of being addicted to is so worth it. This is coming from a guy who got clean off of heroin and cocaine. Quitting smoking really is so incredibly difficult. But I feel so much better now that I never have to worry about it ever again. It's almost been 2 years nicotine free and 3 years cigarette free.

The idea of saying how much people die from smoking is a statistical fallacy as all the numbers are based on definitions, change the definitions, then the numbers change.

Like one can say everyone die from smoking, as everyone have inhaled smoke and theoretically it contributes to shorter life, or we can say nobody dies from smoking as no one would light a cigarette and just fall down dead. any number in between is purely based on what you define as smoking related death and that is as certain as tossing a dice. any number of deaths between 0 and 7 billion would be equality accurate.

Turned out I was found to be ineligible for the jury because I was the godfather of the prosecutor and babysat her and her brother. But I stuck with quitting. I had the most difficulty with what to do with my hands. I bought a box of large straws (the same diameter as a cigarette). I cut them in half and popped them into a zip-lock bag. I could play with my empty cigarette in my fingers while working at my computer, and could even take a drag of air if I wanted.

I smoked for a little over 30 years. When I was diagnosed with pneumonia in my lungs at the doctors office I went out to my car and lit a cigarette and just about blew my eyeballs out coughing so hard. I figured ok, I'll wait a couple days til I can breathe better. 4 days later of not smoking thought Id go outside for a smoke. Then I realized I hadnt gone 4 days without a cigarette for several years. Right then I decided ok, I'll wait another half a day. Then another half a day. Kept doing it half a day at a time. One of the most important things I learned just before I quit smoking (40 years ago), was that aside from all the paradoxical effects of nicotine withdrawal (morning sleepiness, nighttime insomnia, mood swings, etc.), was this: your cravings will arise about as often as you smoke, and will remain intense for only about 5 to 7 minutes, which is about as long as it takes to smoke a cigarette.
So here’s the key to getting rid of the habit, once you’ve determined that you are DONE with it and want to stop forever: As soon as the craving kicks in, get up and do something physical that requires your whole body to do, AND your focus– sweep a garage, shovel a dirt pile from one side of the yard to the other, then back– until the craving stops. As you do this, the cravings will become farther and farther apart, and less and less intense, until you no longer need cigarettes at all.
You MUST NOT go drinking– stay out of pubs, and out of the cars and homes of people who smoke, for a month.
Youll know you’ve quit for real when you smell tobacco smoke, and your first thought is “Echhhh... gross.”

1 week of extreme dreams at night, sweating and anxiety.

All of this is Crap. I started Smoking while I was in 3rd Grade back in 1977. I stopped smoking in 2003. It's a good thing, but a bad thing. That depends on how others may look at it. Now it's November 12th 2021 & it's 18 year's after I have stopped smoking & now I have COPD, ASHMA, & Taking Breathing Machine On a Hourly day to day Basis & BAD HEALTH. COPD alone keeps me from doing the things that I once did. I am not a free man any more. Now I am limited to everything that I want to do but can't. My life as a Grandma, Dad, and a Husband to my family is at a walk a few steps & then stop & breathe about 20 minutes. I'd trade my lifestyle with anyone who is to damned lazy to work or make a living or just have fun. When i was in my teens, I was able to run a mile, now I can't walk across the front room to the bathroom without gasping for air while breathing through a hose just 1/2 way across the floor.
So this video is 110% wrong on some of the people like myself & I know that I am not wrong & not alone. I don't wish this on the most I dislike. But I have it & it isn't a good thing & it'll never get better.
So you believe what you want. 🤔😇🤪👍👍

I started smoking when I was 12, and except for brief breaks every now and then, continued smoking till I was nearly 40. At that point my lungs simply refused to work anymore. At first I thought I got Covid-19, or at least lung cancer, but it ended up just being my lungs being unable to deal with smoke anymore. It's now been almost exactly a year since I quit, and I can definitely say that I don't miss smoking! It was hard to quit in the beginning because every little action was somehow associated with smoking, but after a while I relearned how to do the same actions without needing a cigarette hanging off my lips. A silly example, but for instance taking a dump always felt like I should be having a cigarette while I do it. I knew I had seriously quit smoking when I realised I no longer thought of ciggies anytime I pooped.

I stopped 2 weeks ago, after 16 years of smoking.

Wasn't easy, but wasn't as hard as I'd convinced myself that it would be.

On the other hand I also enjoyed a joint from time to time and figured that I'd still like that little pleasure, this led me to "marshmallow leaf".. a type of brewing herb that can also be used as a padder for joints, in place of tobacco.

Its flavourless and has no smell when burned and only costs £5-$7, for 50grams on amazon.

This way I'm saving money, and enjoying a guilty pleasure still, all the wins!

I started smoking at the very young age of 12. Wished for SO many years that I’d made a better choice. I smoked between a pack and two and a half packs per day for 30 years. I felt terrible. I tried every different method to quit I think. The least effective for me was hypnosis. Others were better… gum helped me last a week, pills lasted 6 months, etc. Nine years ago I hit rock bottom. My life was in turmoil due to a split household so I figured why not try to better myself in regards to smoking while working to improve other areas ?! It worked ! With my head completely in the game I was able to simply put the cigs down and walk away. Now I can look back and know that my health is better and I wasted so much money and time on it. Anyway, to anyone who is trying to quit, please know that you CAN do it ! I would’ve figured I’d be the last on earth to quit and I did it so I know that anyone can !!!

I'm sorry but you are 100% incorrect on everything you state with this. I am a 30 year smoker. My heart rate at excited state is  on average 45 bpm which is low and along with that it does and at average at rest is 30 and does dip to high 20s . My blood pressure is ultra low also. I am full of energy and am on my feet as a mechanic for up to 18 hours 7 days a week between my full time job and my own side shop. My blood is normal thickness and clots normal when cut. My memory is above average and skin does not look stained or discolored. I also have no problem running or jogging an extended period of time. My lungs function normal. I am not the only one like this tho my heart rate is unusually low for a so called healthy none smoker. I on average smoke a pack to pack an a half a day and drink any where from 3 to 8 12oz redbulls daily and have no sleep issues. However I have had a good debate with a number of doctors at freadaurt hospital which is also a medical college about the affects of long term smokers quitting . I say and believe that for a long term smoker one above 10 years should not stop smoking period. If you look at the history of lung disease and cancer to people that currently smoke vers the ones who quit you will find that the quitters are the ones who have the higher risk of cancer and any other issues. The smokers have a far less chance of getting terminally ill. I bet you think I'm just trolling you but I am not. Look up the facts and you will see that I am correct. Now also on that fact vape is supposed to be a healthy alternative to smoking. I stopped 3 years ago and found it difficult to quit, but I decided that this was it and I was going to stop. The effects on my health and wallet just weren't worth it. Previously I had been trying to quit for years with so many failed attempts. I smoked between 25 to 30 cigarettes a day, and had smoked for more than 20 years. I tried everything: patches, gum, inhilators, hypnotherapy, tablets, reading books and more, but nothing worked. So I went cold turkey one day. Stopping smoking was extremely difficult, coughing up tar every morning, swollen gums (due to the chemicals absorbed into my gums), waking up in a sweat and feeling extremely fatigued were just some of the symptoms. I craved a cigarette for 2 years after quitting but don't get them anymore. I have to say that it is the best thing that I have done in entire life, and even now I can't believe that I managed to do it. Even though it's difficult for some and easy for others, I will advice smokers to never give up trying to quit. Cigarettes/nicotine is a drug, nothing more. There's no real pleasure and it's not worth your health.

If you smoke for social, physical, emotional reasons, if you have smoked for a long time I can assure you quitting will change you, change your life. Other things in your life will seem easy by comparison because they are. At 55 it's been almost 20 years since I quit. I shudder to think what my health would be like if I hadn't quit. You can do it too. We're rooting for you.

Most importantly smoking is a routine, and once you do it during these times:
-Morning smokes
-After food smokes
-Stress and break from work smokes
-Good times smokes
-Goodnight smokes

You're pretty much setting yourself up to fail. Every time you do these everyday tasks, you will now associate them with the urge to nicotine, making the addiction even worse.

I believe best thing to do is to see how much of your smoking routine you can replace with healthier routines like working out, that way you also remind yourself how unhealthy it would be to return smoking.

Also, try and stay away from whatever environment you usually smoke in, whether it is a place in your home, on work, or even a friend, staying away from objects you associate with smoking, the less reminded you are of your habit.

My solution was to stop drinking, as I usually fell back as soon as I touched alcohol.

Over 15 years I smoked and especially last two years per day I was smoking around 35-40 cigarette... There was no moment that I was not smoking. I took a really though decision and I really decided to stop. Since 15th March 2020 I'm not smoking and I can tell you it is really about decision. If you can show patience to read this that's mean you have patience to stop cigarette as well so let me tell you why I think 'the decision' is the key. As I heavy smoker previous years I attempt to stop and it took maximum a couple of days Or weeks to start back. But I guess in my mind I was never quitting smoking, I was counting days and I was smoking in my dreams. So I was waiting for a moment that I can start back to smoking. This time when u see that it even effects my daily routine like walking or climbing a few stairs, I felt very bad. I felt like I have a machine that I didn't care enough and now in age of 29-30 this machine is collapsing. I imagined myself in the worst condition and I said 'this is not what I choose for myself' and decided definitely stopping and after that decision I start the work. I start to talk Myself whenever I wanted to smoking and I gave myself reasons why I stop and always talked to myself as if I'm advising someone else. This time even in my dreams when people offer me cigarette I was rejecting, after rejecting even in my dreams when I wake up I said ' I did it I am not a smoker anymore' . Today I'm much healthier and little heavier cause some snacks sometimes came to my help first couple of months. However I'm feeling much better by alllll means... See if you really read till here that's mean you already decided, tell me you wanna leave your prime times (30-70 years old) with coughing pain and erectal dysfunction or really want to "live" Your life... You choose to start smoking and you can choose not to do... Will not be very easy but will be very beautiful journey... If you 'decided' you don't need luck so I'm not wishing you 'good luck'...

I replaced smoking with lollypops and blowing soap bubbles.
After each time blowing the bubbles, I pretended to be heavily relieved.

The first time buying lollypops instead of cigarettes was my reward for stopping for a week..
I ripped the package apart as soon as coming out of the market. My hands were shaking. Sucking the lollypop as if it was the hardest drug in the world. It was then that I realized a child was watching me. A blonde little angel standing right next to me with her mother. I asked her if she also wants a lolly. She looked up to her mother. The mother asked her "Do you?". She reluctantly nodded. "Take one", her mother said, and the girl didn't hesitate a second. Smiling with genuine bliss all over her face.

That smile has buried my smoking habit forever.
Since then, I have made many children smile this way with bubbles and lollies, instead of being a bad role model and poisoning the very air they breathe. And I have finally started smiling this way myself.

The wife n i quit smokin about 8 yrs ago. We feel better, food tastes better, n the money not wasted on smokes goes to our hobbies. We spend alot of time with our kids doin activites that we never did while smoking. U wanna quit smoking? U need a few things to assist n drive u to wanna quit. 1) We prayed n ask God to take the craving away, n He did. 2) Will power! We wanted to quit, for not only out benefit, but our kids as well. N no, we never smoked in the house or vehicle, nor near the kids. 3) Alternative to smoking. Myself, i would get a sucker when i felt the urge to smoke. Within a week, i didnt feel the urge anymore. Just have to find somethin that will take your mind away from wanting/needing a cig.

The number one help in quitting is askin for help. In any situation for that matter. One that can help the most, believe it or not, is God! With Him, anything is possible!!!!

If you have trouble with bad breath, when you quit smoking, it will improve. Your teeth in overall will improve cause smoking cause damage.

After a week of quitting, I got a lot of pustules. After 15 years of smoking, my body had a lot of toxins in the body. It was just a way for my body to get rid of them. The pustules went away soon after. After that also your skin, especially your face starts to rejuvenate, looks a lot smoother.

One thing that people really need to pay attention to, when quitting smoking, you start eating much more, really a lot. You can help that with eating more healthy (light) snacks. What I did, every time i wanted to smoke, eat chewing gum, stopped me from smoking and eat to much. And go to the gym, 3-4 times a week. That way it will reduce the chance to get overweight.

In overall even with getting a little overweight, best choice i made, feeling more calm, focused, more energy, more money cause cigarettes cost a lot and more time to do other stuff, cause all those cigarette breaks do take some time. When you smoke 10x a day, 5 minutes per cigarette, that’s 50 minutes of your time.

Well, I've opened that pack of 20 cigarettes and just like that I've put it in the driver's door pocket and left it there as a memory of the last bought cigarettes pack.

The only way to do this is to want to prove to yourself that you're strong. You gotta know a simple equation :
Dreaming big + Embracing Reality + HUGE DETERMINATION = SUCCESFUL and WEALTHY LIFE

The only way to get that huge determination is through discipline, and this is a great way to discipline yourself , but it shouldn't be the only one

Cigarettes are the worst addiction ever!  But if you smoke, you know that.  I finally made it off them on my eight try!  I started when I was 29 and finally quit when I was 59, with 2-3 year periods of quitting and going back to them.  What madness..... not a one of all the brands i tried, which was near all of them over the years, really 'tasted' good, and all of them left me with every physical problem I could think of...... Get this, from the top down I had headaches, food taste problems, nose problems, throat problems, lung problems, indigestion and stomach problems, problems with my bowels, and of course, hemorrhoids!....... ask anyone who smokes about the problems they've experienced.  And, likely you'll die young like my wife, at 64, and even the Reynolds of the cigarette companies have died at 59 and 60 years of age, look it up........  So I developed the concept of a 'Smoke Out', which goes like this:  On the designated day to quit you buy a couple of packs of your favorite brand and start smoking...... one right after the other, and you keep smoking with as little break as possible between them, until you start to choke up.  Then keep smoking until you really can't smoke another one, then make one big last effort and smoke your last one, ever.  Believe me, you won't want another for awhile, for me it was just enough to get me into the next day.  Sounds crazy doesn't it ......Anyway that's the way I quit... and then one by one all those body problems started to go, the cough and the foul taste in my mouth, the upset stomach.  But you'll need to be attentive, as the desire will be back shortly, in a couple of days or so....., and then about 6 months down the line I finally felt like I made it.  And I had!  Best of luck to all.........

I hope that my journey can inspire some people to quit smoking. I've been a smoker since I was 16, and has been for the last 22 years. For me quitting was like breaking up a toxic relationship with someone. I got married 2 years ago, and I feel like my relationship with cigarette was harming my family physically and emotionally, so once I started looking at cigarette as a person, like an abusive ex or mistress, it got a lot easier. The reason for this approach is, as long as we see cigarette as an object, we'll always feel like we're in control, but once you start looking at it as a person that's manipulating you to burn your money and your years, chances are you'll stop seeing that person. I started seeing her (cigarette) less and less, and at some point I feel like I was just keeping her because I simply got used to having her around for certain things, it became clear that she was doing more harm than good, I started visualizing certain daily routines without smoking, once I feel I was mentally adjusted I knew it was over, there was no reason for me to keep seeing her. Then one day I just walked away from her and never looked back. Easily one of the best decision I made in my life. I hope this comment will be helpful to some people who's trying to quit. I wish you all the best, and I promise you that you'll won't regret it!

I dont know if this helps anyone, but here my story of smoking, quitting and dealing with the after effects.
I started my career about 2 years ago. At the tail end of 2019, pressure of work was mounting and shit was about the hit the fan. It didnt, but it did turn me towards cigarettes. I was a social smoker for years, smoking at most 10-15 a month, at the height of it. Usually it was less than 10 a year. But when I started smoking regularly, I was averaging 5-6 a day.

Then the covid lockdowns happened and there was no cigarettes being sold anywhere, at least legally. Some people were selling their stocks at very steep prices @300% costs, in shady alleys. I got some. Soon regulations were relaxed, and cigarettes were selling legally. I bought 4 packs, just in case.

After a few months, I gave up on denial and accepted that I am now addicted. I am not really that good at quitting bad habits. I looked at my pack, and saw a couple of last cigarettes left. The only way I could quit was to never buy any ever. And thats what I did. Smoked the last remaining ones and never bought another pack. What followed was a shit show.

WIthin 48 hrs, I suffered the first ever anxiety attack in my 23 years of life, at the dead of the night. It felt like I was dying. A week later, another, and soon they started being frequent. It was hard to get hold of a doctor due to the pandemic so had to wait another few weeks before I could visit one. The doc prescribed every blood test under the sun, along with an ECG. Gave a bunch of antidepressants and statins. It turns out that was a very bad idea(and the doctor should have known better) as that combo gave me statin induced myopathy. Went to another doctor who was more experienced, an this time it worked out slowly over the last 6 months.

Though my health has deteriorated over the course of the lockdown and WFH for close to a year, I dont crave cigarettes or get anxiety attacks anymore.

I tried quitting so many times but it never really worked, until last year. I found a little cheat that would support me.

I always wanted to try out the Ramadan to find out if it was doable when your not religious. So I joined in last year. The rules of the Ramadan is that you are not allowed to eat or drink when the sun is risen and tabacco / alcohol is not allowed at all. It takes about a month.

Well the first days were quite hard because of the constant desire for food and water. This was actually a good thing. Because my mind was mainly focussed on these primary things I kinda forgot about the desire of a smoke. And because of the no alcohol rule my selfcontrol wasnt challenged.

After a couple of days I was really used to my new temporarily lifestyle. The hungry feeling was gone and so with it the desire to smoke. Haven’t had that desire come back since last April. I can proudly say that I quitted smoking. (And also lost some unnecessary bodyfat)

Now I understand that there arent alot of people who wish to do an entire Ramadan to stop smoking. Therefore the advice I want to give you is that you need to find something that will distract your mind. Find a bigger desire then your smoking desire and you will soon forget the taste of a cigarette and replace it with a proud feeling.

Ps. Kinda funny how I needed the help from a foreign god to actually let me stop smoking.

For everyone who is reading this and wants to stop that's what helped me quitting:

First of all, throw everything away. Every cigarette, and not needed but I would recommend lighters aswell in case you find a cigarette under table or so.
Then find a thing you can replace smoking. I used to smoke a lot during breaks from school and then from work. When I quit I replaced it reading. I was never a fan of reading, but everytime I went outside for the break I start reading. I wasn't enjoying it, but I had to replace it with something.


What you really have to prevent:

Hanging out with friends who smoke. I started again a few times because my friend smelled like cigarettes.
Try to not replace it with another addiction like alcoholism or anything else bad.


Last of all, try to forget about cigarettes and nicotine. And don't see it as a challenge for lifetime to stop. Instead see it like a daily challenge. Because everyday it gets less harder and less harder. I wish you all the luck in the world to stop :)

I have been smoking for over 30 years. I've tried everything I know to give up many times, to the point that I felt it was a hopeless cause. Finally, I decided to take it one second at a time and tell nobody that I was trying to quit...not even myself. It worked! I have now been three months without a cigarette. It wasn't at all easy and I still occasionally fancy a smoke, but it is not the extreme craving that it once was and the feeling passes within seconds. Most of the time I no longer think about smoking at all. I know just how hard it is for smokers to quit and I absolutely never criticize a smoker. It is very hard to quit but so very satisfying if you do beat the habit. Never stop trying, but don't feel weak if you fail. Just be determined to try again...and good luck!

Let me share you my story if that helps. I was smoking since I was 16 (don't ask me how).1-2 per day.
Got a job then it increased to 4-5 per day (I took it as a stress reliever or for break)

In last two years (2019-2020), count increased up to 12-18 per day. It is not like my body demanding it, I just made habits like "before dinner", "after dinner", "after watching TV", "before sleeping" etc. So it was just a task like other daily routine task.
I couldn't left that during pandemic as well.
One day, I felt breathing issue & due to pandemic I thought I got Corona so I got scared, so I didn't smoke for 2-3 days and I was normal again. So I started smoking again.
Now, I started feeling some weight on my lungs, in silence I was able to hear bubble sound from my lungs and of course I am no more an athletic person that I used to be because I exausts easily.

So on July 16th, I quit smoking (cold turkey). First 2 days were pretty normal and I was able to control myself by thinking about the health benefits I will get but on 3-5 days, I got bad urges to smoke at least 1. (This happened for only 2 days)
From day 3-5, I drink tea couple of times.

On coming day or two, I slept for long (14 hours a day), if I am awake I will feel like smoking but if I am sleeping my body won't demand.

Now its September end. i don't even get any feeling about smoking.
I am not sure about focus and health improvement but I can observe that I am much energetic than before.

So, if I can stop smoking after 20 years than you can also do it.

Do it because there is no fun in dieing via lung cancer.

Your body is a temple please take good care of it

The Bible never directly mentions smoking. There are principles, however, that definitely apply to smoking. First, the Bible commands us not to allow our bodies to become "mastered" by anything. "Everything is permissible for me—but not everything is beneficial. Everything is permissible for me—but I will not be mastered by anything" (1 Corinthians 6:12). Smoking is undeniably strongly addictive. Later in the same passage we are told, "Do you not know that your body is a temple of the Holy Spirit, who is in you, whom you have received from God? You are not your own; you were bought at a price. Therefore honor God with your body" (1 Corinthians 6:19-20). Smoking is undoubtedly very bad for your health. Smoking has been proven to damage the lungs and the heart.

Can smoking be considered "beneficial" (1 Corinthians 6:12)? Can it be said that smoking is truly honoring God with your body (1 Corinthians 6:20)? Can a person honestly smoke "for the glory of God" (1 Corinthians 10:31)? We believe that the answer to these three questions is a resounding "no." As a result, we believe that smoking is a sin and therefore should not be practiced by followers of Jesus Christ.

Some argue against this view by pointing to the fact that many people eat unhealthy foods, which can be just as addicting and just as bad for the body. As an example, many people are so helplessly addicted to caffeine that they cannot function without their first cup of coffee in the morning. While this is true, how does that make smoking right? It is our contention that Christians should avoid gluttony and excessively unhealthy eating. Yes, Christians are often hypocritical by condemning one sin and condoning another, but, again, this does not make smoking honoring to God.

Another argument against this view of smoking is that many godly men have been smokers, such as the famous British preacher C.H. Spurgeon, who was known to smoke cigars. Again, we do not believe this argument holds any weight. We believe Spurgeon was wrong for smoking. Was he otherwise a godly man and fantastic teacher of God’s Word? Absolutely! Does that make all of his actions and habits honoring to God? No.

In stating that smoking is a sin, we are not stating that all smokers are unsaved. There are many true believers in Jesus Christ who smoke. Smoking does not prevent a person from being saved. Nor does it cause a person to lose salvation. Smoking is no less forgivable than any other sin, whether for a person becoming a Christian or a Christian confessing his/her sin to God (1 John 1:9). At the same time, we firmly believe that smoking is a sin that should be forsaken and, with God’s help, overcome.

Almost 2 months smoke free and this time I won’t go back. I’ve quit smoking twice before that, second time I went without for over 1 year but one moment of weakness when drunk and I was fully back at it again. (In the past 2 years I have had alcohol maybe 5 times and I don’t plan to have any in the future!) I wanted to quit again and this time for real but kept making excuses for myself. My moment of clarity was when I was really short on money and it was either food or cigarettes. Made me realize a lot... First 3 days are the worst but honestly if you stop feeling so sorry for yourself and just push trough for once it’s really not that hard. Everybody knows that smoking causes cancer and heart disease-- But this isn't what killed my Mom.


COPD has been talked about more in the past few years. This is a
disease that makes it hard to get all of the air out of your lungs, thus
making it hard to get air in... Making it difficult to breath -- This
was only an accomplice in the murder of my mother.

Something nobody really talks about, and the thing that actually took my mother is called PAD, Peripheral artery disease.


The chemicals in Cigarettes cause your veins and arteries to constrict.
Eventually this causes them to begin to collapse and you begin to
loose circulation-- especially to your arms and legs.

In the
past 9 months, it began to happen to Mom. All of a sudden moms legs
began to swell and get ugly, painful blisters. This is because fluids
that go into the legs couldn't get out (the veins had deteriorated too
far).

These blisters, not able to get enough oxygen (because the
COPD, and poor circulation) ulcerated... Even though we were seeing a
doctor and using very expensive medicine, the wounds just weren't
getting better.

The thing about wounds that don't heal, and that
aren't getting the nutrients they need, is that the tissue begins to
die... they also don't get the healing factors that fight everyday
bacteria.

In a shorter time that you could possibly imagine,
Mom's wounds got infected, and she had to go to the hospital. They were
able to surgically remove the dead tissue from her legs (without having
to amputate), but unfortunately for everybody who knew Mom, the
bacteria that had invaded was mostly resistant to drugs.

A
resistant Bacteria, COPD not allowing enough healing Oxygen, and a
circulatory system that didn't allow for delivery of healing factors
created a perfect storm.

Cigarettes killed my Mom at 1pm on March
16th, 2020. It wasn't Cancer. It wasn't Heart Disease. It wasn't a
stroke or heart attack (Although, cigarettes are responsible for these
in others.) My mom was killed the PAD with COPD as a secondary factor.

Cigarettes are bad. Everybody kinda knows this. It's your own personal choice, if you smoke, please consider stopping.


I don't know if stopping would have saved my moms life 9 months ago...
the damage had begun. But a year ago... She knew they were bad...
Three years ago... Maybe the COPD wouldn't have been so bad that her
lips sometime turned blue...

All I know, if my Mother had never smoked cigarettes she wouldn't have died yesterday.

48 hours without a cigarette. The cravings were intense the first day, but the 2nd day not so much. It's still hard though, my body is constantly fighting with my mind about smoking and not smoking. I started smoking when I was 15, and I'm now turning 26 this month, so 11 years of smoking. I feel like the 2nd day wasn't as bad as the first, but I really feel like the 3rd day is going to be the most intense. Thats when all the nicotine in your body is gone, so the real withdrawal will begin. But between sucking on mints, and taking several naps. I feel like I'll push through. Does the British government REALLY want people to stop smoking, considering the amount of money they make out of it (currently about £12 billion per year)? They keep raising the price of tobacco but they never consider making it illegal which they WOULD do IF they were serious about getting everyone to stop. See quote and article below.

"The government takes in a total of about £9.5 billion in tobacco duties and the Tobacco Manufacturers' Association has told us another £2.5 billion goes to the Treasury in VAT. So the Treasury is taking in about £12 billion directly from tobacco sales. Even here, you could argue indirect benefits such as taxes from people employed in the tobacco industry and the contribution of tobacco sales to the economy as a whole could add to the Treasury's take."

Full article here:
https://fullfact.org/economy/does-smoking-cost-much-it-makes-treasury/

I have recently successfully quit.

Sad people smoke a lot. I was very sad as a youth, young adult & adult. I began to smoke in my early teens. I gradually became a heavy smoker for nearly twenty years. I was smoking approximately 3 1/2 packs per day of the strongest filterless cigarettes on the market when I finally decided to stop allowing cigarette manufacturers to control my life. I quit cold turkey one day over thirty years ago and had the addiction beaten within seventy-two hours. I'm not saying it was easy; it wasn't the least bit easy, but I did it...and if I could do it anyone can do it. I am no longer sad but happy. You current smokers are sad people, too (like I was), but you don't have to be; all of you can finally be happy, too.

One method to quit smoking and never look back;

1. Read up on the various ways smoking harms you ( fear of something real can be an effective avoidance strategy.e.g. l fear racist sociopaths & avoid breathing in their smoke pollution if possible ( hehe. I'm not suggesting the two are positively correlated,but?)

2. Take the easy route and get some nicotine alternative such as vapes , gum or patches.

3. I'm still on stage three after not wanting a ciggerette for over ten years. I.e. I enjoy a nicotine fix. Whilst nicotine may have some side effects ( as does caffeine) they pale in comparison to the potential diseases associated with breathing in smoke.

Here's the thing...you need will power. I gave up around 2 years ago. I'd tried loads of times before that but it never worked because I didn't really have the will. This time I did and I have never felt any of the withdrawal symptoms. Weird isn't it? Some of you will think I'm lying but I'm not and some will say I was a light smoker but no...20 -30 even 40 a day for years.... It was just that I was truly determined and I think that somehow the will power turned off the usual symptoms...or over rode them somehow... I have found myself occasionally dreaming that I was smoking...I remember dreaming I had started smoking again and I was very disappointed..But that's as close as I came to smoking or any withdrawal symptoms.
I was very happy to find it was only a dream :)
Anyway, since I threw the cigarettes out of the car window around 2 years ago I haven't had a single cigarette or even been tempted.
I don't know how this works exactly, I'd like to but all I do know is that it does work. It's a mental attitude; If you can be determined enough, and have enough will power, then you can stop easily....

I had been a smoker since I was 15, now I am almost 23. I remember how strong each cigarette was when I started, just one would satisfy my daily dose of nicotine, and yet I wasn't even addicted. I started smoking out of curiosity. The first cigarette had a bad effect on me. I started being dizzy and felt like I would collapse, but I still continued just to feel tough in the group of people I used to hang out with. It's funny when you walk down the street and see a kid with a cigarette, surrounded by some friends, thinking he's cool. I was just like that! Later on it turns on you, both the cigarette and people you hang out with. I never smoked to feel any influence of the cigar, there wasn't any! People who tell that, tell lies. I have a strong mind and I used to leave smoking for like 5-6 months, but I would eventually return back to it. One of the key factors was the group I was in. When all people around you smoke and defend the idea of smoking, you cannot even argue with them. You cannot tell them that you want to stop, because even if you do, they would continue and you would end up as a passive smoker if you plan on hanging out with them. They would not stop smoking because of you! I have been there. It took me a while to finally admit that I was addicted. It was always like "I had a bad day at work" or something like that. It wasn't even about friends, it was about my personal time with a cigarette! Over the time I smoked more and more until it started to interfere with my health and it became obvious to me how bad that is. Coughing every day, feeling unwilling to do anything, even grumpy a bit - those were the starting symptoms. Then I started having headaches, and coughing becomes a reflex, you don't even control it anymore. So one day I was drinking water and I started coughing in the middle of it so I almost choked. It happened at least 5 times until one day I woke up and told myself: that's it. The worst part is when you need to break some relationships in order to save you from the smoke, but it's worth it. People who support your smoking habits are not your friends, because they support you killing yourself and a friend doesn't do that. I stopped and will never return. Only after 2 weeks you will start feeling much better and energized. Do it! Stop smoking and drop the f bomb on all the people who say you shouldn't! Trust me, the world will become much better place.
Lived 5 years  without cigarettes ☺️ LIFE IS AWESOME ☺️     .     BEST OF LUCK.

I found a free, smoking cessation class, started at 6pm every monday. I was a smoker of 18 years. So my first day in the class, the first thing the instructor says is, your quit date, will be February 24th 2015. First thing I said to myself, there is no way in hell, it's only going to be 6 weeks, I'm not quitting. I think it started on 1/12/2015 or 1/19/2015.

So I had already planned a trip out of state, already had bought the plane ticket. So I missed the second class, and as I was coming back home, I seriously debated, just not going to the class and continuing to smoke. By this point, I had just been laid off from work, got my severance pay, or was collecting it, and I figured, well I'm not bringing in any money, let's see what this class is about, so I did go, and continued going until the end.

We were given a book, just showed like, how much money you would spend on cigarettes over X years, and different things you could do to help change your mindset etc. etc. What was really nice however, was that, about 2 weeks out from the class ending, we were given a free months supply of quit smoking aids, lozenges, patch, gum or the medication you can take for it (forgot the name).

So, I ended up getting the 2mg lozenge, and I used them for about 2 to 3 weeks. After a while, the cravings just were no longer there. It is possible to quit, and I think for me personally, this was the best way, because I had no idea about how to quit. For me, the cravings were very strong. I even took a piece of paper, rolled it around an ink pen, taped it together, because in my brain, I was so used to getting up, going outside and having that movement of bringing the cigarette up to your mouth, so I did it with the rolled up piece of paper, with the lozenge in between my cheek and gum, and that really helped me along the way.

To this day, I have been smoke free since 2/24/2015 and we all got a certificate of completion, dated 3/16/2015. It was right when I started the class, I had been laid off from work.

Do I feel better? Hell yes. And at my new job, I can tell who the smokers are. When you smoke, you do carry a disgusting odor around with you.

Oh and lastly, I quit because after 8 months of constant coughing up phlegm, I was getting worried. Once I quit smoking, that all went away.

You DO NOT LOOK COOL SMOKING!  In fact , most people look down on people who smoke and believe smokers are less intelligent. (not my opinion, it was in a study).    Smokers are often treated as outcasts. You'll find them lurking like creepers behind buildings and out- of-the-way places (in all kinds of bad weather)  Their cars stink, as do their clothes, breath and hair.  No matter how much gum and perfume you use to cover ithe smell , it lingers. Smokers may shy away from hugging or being too close to nonsmokers because ithe smell is embarrassing. When parents of small children walk by, they often give  smokers dirty looks because you are harming their kids with your smoke. I could go on, but you get the picture.  I know this because I've smoked for 10 years.  Admittedly, there were times when I thought I looked cool doing it, but I was wrong and being stupid  I thought I could quit 'whenever', but it's so much harder than I ever expected and it SUCKS!!  I'm on my third day without a cigarette and I have to keep reminding myself of the many positive reasons there are for doing so.  I can do this and you can, too!!

Ive been smoking for about 9 years, on and off. Im a recovering binge drinker of 7 yeara. I haven't had a drop of alcohol in 10 days. My only urge to drink is after work. But ive been slamming back bottles of water whenever I have the urge to drink. However, I have a chronic sporadic cigarette habit, the only time I've ever had luck to quit, is either supplement tobacco with weed or cold turkey tobacco. Weed is too expensive and I don't smoke it anymore, just tobacco. The only logical way to quit smoking, is to chew copious amounts of none nicotine chewing gum, and exercise. Get an urge to smoke? Do a 100 push ups and get an endorphin high, and slam about 16 oz of water. The faster you get the nicotine out of your system, the faster route to recovery. Meditation helps too, if you can get to it. Continuously tell yourself that the shit is bad and every cig is going to take 10 minutes off your life. Its a tough windy road to travel, but though perseverance and mental strength anyone can achieve this. Mind over matter. Mind over matter. Mind over matter. Good luck.

I just feel sad for the upcoming generation.

They will live in a world now where in most 'developed' countries, cigarettes are 'hidden' behind a curtain (out of sight = out of mind) and the cost of cigarettes in Australia now has topped around AUD$50 for a pack of 40/50.

I smoke roll your own, one 50 gram packet costs around 50$ and lasts me 2 weeks or more.

The point is, the government is not truly committed towards your health and well being, only the money (sales tax).

Because the government has in effect stolen all this money and paid something else off with it - whether that was the Welfare Benefits, a new highway, a new pay rise for themselves, etc etc etc, without going to what it was meant to be spent on, it was meant to go towards medical treatment for the future anticipated sickness of the smoker, and not for anything else.

Smoking is perceived as a social and economic problem.
If it is so, then why not get rid of it?
Because it is so far deeply ingrained in to our social fabric that it has practically become part of the Human Genome. It is now the 47th Chromosome.

Well, the bottom line is, if smoking does not kill you, something else will.
You can go out coughing or wheezing with bad lungs or with a bullet in the head with healthy lungs, either way, you are gone, age is immaterial.

When my uncle was around 13, he took up smoking, he let his grades drop significantly, stopped cutting his hair and basically just lived with his mom. By the age of 22, he was noticing how negatively smoking was effecting his health. For example, he wasn't even able to climb the stairs without getting winded, and he was only 22 years old. That's when he decided that he could not live like this for the rest of his life. He decided to cut his hair, go back to school to boost his grades, and most of all, he quit smoking cold turkey (with no vapes, nicotine sprays, or anything like that.) It was not easy, but he said it was worth it. He now works in Fort McMurray Alberta at the oil sands testing levels of pollution in water and air to help regulate the air and water quality for the wildlife and the locals, but in his spare time, he goes camping, he hunts, plays lacrosse and he frequently runs marathons in sub-zero degree Albertan weather.  (Fahrenheit) Quitting smoking cold-turkey is not easy, but it is not impossible, and when you have been without smokes for about a year, you will be able to notice the amazing difference it makes. My uncle has been for almost 25 years without cigarettes and he says he still, in his 40's, feels many times better now than he did when he was 21.

I quit smoking five years ago. I’m 32, meaning I quit during a time where there is a 97% chance to relapse due to the arrogance of youth.

On a bad day, I was smoking at least a pack and a half; it should also be noted that I am an asthmatic, and I was often using an emergency nebulizer while holding a lit cigarette in my other hand.

Stupid, right? What made me quit was when I realized that the nebulizer and steroids I were on worked, but it still took a serious effort to breathe—choking for air during the night did it for me.

The first five days were absolutely horrendous. I ran out of my house and onto the street barefoot trying to find a way to cope with the addiction. I called my dad, who told me I can’t die from quitting. A few more days passed, and soon, I finally started doing the talking (instead of the cigarette), and never will go back. Now I don’t take any steroids, and I haven’t used my rescue inhaler or nebulizer for nearly a year.

If you are in your 20s and want to quit, you can! And if you do it now, you will recover even more than you ever will by putting it off till later.

Statistics, statistics and only statistics ! All of this is BS people.I'm 56 and I smoked for more than forty years. Before quitting, 7 years ago, I was smoking 2 packs a day and more. I quit cold turkey and IT WAS VERY EASY TO DO since I was really fed up with tobacco smoking and I was fed up of being seen as a CRIMINAL, because I smoked. I have to mention also that financially, I couldn't afford it anymore. Never took even a single puff since and I'm pretty sure I won't for the rest of my life ! Seven years later, my lungs are still wheezing even though I walk 1 hour a day and i even do some jogging in the summertime (around 8 kilometers 3 times a week). It's the same for my blood pressure. It was hi when I smoked and it is still hi to the point that I need medications to lower it. Exercising and healthy eating ain't enough ! So....the only true thing is I feel better because I decided to do so and not come back to smoking. Now, I'm the one looking at the smokers as criminals.....lol...not at all. I respect smokers and I even let them smoke in my home, it doesn't bother me at all. If, in certain cases, the secondary smoke is too much to handle (makes me wheeze), I'l open a window to let the smoke out and that's it. I have no kids at home and I'm single so.... Never will I make smokers feel UNDESIRABLE as a was made to feel by society. By this I'm not saying it is not ok to quit, but if you believe in the crap shown in this video and you've been smoking for a while. You're in for a very deceptive surprise ! Sorry to spoil the fun...and between you and me, weed is much worth smoking than tobacco. It puts a smile on your face every time and soon it will be much more affordable (when legalized in Canada) !

My strategy for quitting (when I finally get motivated to, work makes this a tough one. ), is instead of just giving it all up at once, I will spend week 1 reducing my intake of cigarettes, 3 a day, week 2 will be 2 a day...then it will drop to zero. I will try to flush nicotine out of my system with water, healthy diet, and excersise. Another tip I was reading was to stay as busy as possible, try to reduce any down time until you're in bed, you can't smoke if you're asleep.

Quitting smoking is one of the hardest challenges I have been through. The first 72 hours are not the most difficult though, as most guides will say. That is because in the beginning everybody is enthusiastic and hyped about quitting, and that energy sees you through the first stage. The worst for me was month 1-3 where I was depressed, suffering from inexplicable stress, mood swings and irritability. It is this stage that needs that extra resolve to avoid relapse. And you really have to be determined that this habit no longer suits you or represents you. It was my 5th attempt that was the successful one, everyone is different and responds in a different way, but it really helps to learn about the science of addiction and what to expect. That way when the severe withdrawal kicks in you know what is going on in your brain and you manage it better. Good luck!

After compiling a list of activities that will benefit me tremendously, I have decided that today is the day that I finally quit smoking. I realise that many smokers relapse after a few days but I think this is the push I need to achieve my future goals and start the snowball effect of doing some thing uncomfortable for long periods of time. Many people don’t realise that by doing difficult things, you become grounded and a beacon of positive energy. After heavily researching and throuh personal experience I have founad this to be the case. One example was when I jumped off a cliff into the sea which terrified me. After doing that I felt a surge of energy and motivation and people could tell. All i’m trying to say is that there is cause and effect relationship between doing something hard and receiving positive feedback. It’s as though your brain is rewarding you for doing something out of your comfort zone. Quitting smoking is the first step in this. I hope others try as well.

I was smoking 40 over cigarettes a day. Three months ago, my chest started to hurt so badly and I decided to stop. During the first few days, I suffered from nicotine deprivation and the symptoms were similar to that of epilepsy. Couldn't focus on my work and accumulation of saliva in my mouth to the point where it would foam every few minutes. The first two weeks were unbearable and I had to chew on used filters (yes, collecting used cigarette buds from my work colleagues and chewing on the filter just to get the smell of cigarettes into my mouth and nostrils). After a month or so, things got much better and I didn't have much withdrawal symptoms anymore. Unfortunately, the effects of smoking has taken its toll on me such as dark yellow eyes, black teeth, stained fingernails etc. For those of you who are not heavy smokers, I sincerely urge you to stop now, it's not going to be easy but remember that over the years, it would be nearly impossible and you wouldn't want to be chewing on your work colleagues cigarette buds would you?

That is a trip down memory lane the day i quit smoking not exactly 11 calendar years ago but damn close to it from four years on/off every month smoking with low strength cancer sticks, I had the exact same symptoms described above but due to my extremely strong willpower combined with family and friends at the time to push through the withdrawal symptoms i overcame them.

The following information is my own personal experience from quitting smoking and my body healing the damage that was done.

Inside two weeks after quitting
I started to remove the shit out of my lungs with a lot of coughing and i noticed i was getting healthier again i could ride my pushbike harder every day with more open lung capacity with deeper and longer breaths allowing me to go faster and faster and sustain it for longer and even with longer walking times between stops had also improved.

3 months after quitting:

28 years old, I used to smoke for 11 years 15 cigarettes a day on average. I quit smoking for a week now.

The positive effects are close to instantaneous. I can enjoy riding bicycles, I don't have shortness of breath and I'm feeling overall way better. I still use patches though, as my dependency to nicotine is quite strong, but I don't sleep with them on and everyday I try to postpone the moment I'm putting them on. It's not easy, I cough a lot, I am not extremely motivated at work, I have difficulty to sleep sometimes and I often tell myself that ''a little puff couldn't hurt'', but I haven't touched a cigarette for a week and I sure as sh** don't plan to do so ever again.

I cannot wait for the final moment when I don't even think about it and it's completely out of my system, it will take one, two, probably three months, but I'll get there eventually.

Some times I watch a movie and see someone enjoying a cigarette.  I think, gee that cigarette does look good.  I watch as the actor inhales and exhales and I can almost taste it.  I was a two to three pack a day smoker and smoked for many years.  It has also been many years since I gave up cigarettes.  Once you make your mind up that you don't want to throw thousands of dollars away on cigarettes and you don't want to die a horrible death and you don't want to smell like a walking ash tray and you don't want your house decor to be ugly tar orange, you'll quit.  You can use various aids to help get you on the track to stop but unless you are truly serious about it, you won't stop or you'll go back.  Like an alcoholic, I am a cigaholic.  I don't crave cigarettes.  However, there are those times I see someone smoking and for whatever reason, in that brief moment, there is that desire for a smoke.  I never give in because I know how difficult it is to quit.

I smoked for 14 years, quit for 8. Within 3 months of quitting I was having such extreme mood swings I went to the doctor and got on antidepressants. I gained 40lbs over the next few months and eventually was put on medications for cholesterol and blood pressure. The original antidepressant stopped working as well and I was switched to a new one. The side effects of the antidepressants were additional weight gain.

All in all, I gained 80lbs. That's not entirely due to the medications, but they did contribute greatly.I started dieting and regularly exercising and lost 50lbs, but my blood pressure never went down and my cholesterol levels stayed the same. I injured myself and could no longer exercise and by the time I healed up i was completely out of the habit. Eventually the 2nd antidepressant stopped working and I was switched to Cymbalta which has a reputation to make people want to drink and smoke. I think it has to do with the way it effects the dopamine receptors in your brain.

I began smoking again on the odd weekend when I was at a show or out with friends. Then it became every weekend, then 1 after work each day plus on the weekends. Now I am smoking a pack a day again.

I'm going to die of heart disease at this rate, but I never have suicidal thoughts now that I've started smoking again, so that's a plus.

To all people, who are soo proud that they only smoke weed, I have a message for you: In 2014, -15, -16 I smoked weed about every two weeks. After a while, I started to notice that some things are different, but I couldn't really describe what it was; I just somehow felt weird.
So I quit it at once at the end of 2016 and immedeatly felt the changes:
-My motivation to do things came back
-I wanted to go to sleep earlier so that I have more Energy for the next day
-Once again I've started with sports (running in the morning and basketball, aswell as Muay Thai Fighting)
-My grades improved
-My social skills improved, I wasn't as boring in conversations as before; that lead to more friends and contacts
-I'm about to get a girlfriend right now
When I look back at the times before 2017, I pitty myself for being such a miserable pothead, but luckily, I aint one anymore.
I want you to know, that I started to smoke at the end of 2016, too.
It definitely was a mistake, too, but if I had to decide between the two evils, I would take cigaretts. Weed doesn't damage your body as much, but it destroys you from the inside in a subtle, unconcious way, which you yourself don't even notice.
But nonetheless, my goal was to reduce or even quit my smoking habit by April, so that I can live a completely free life.
That's my story, feel free to ask questions or comment😂

except that in polluted air smoking doesn't really affect most of that, since you already inhaling tar, excess co2, burned rubber microflakes, various airborne chemicals produced by heavy industry, heavy metals from water etc.

Smoking in such conditions would not affect anything, but all the upsides of tobacco still remain - such as vitamin PP and nicotine acid as chemicals which lower Alzheimer's disease development ratios up to 10x times, potential prevention of naturally occurring Parkinson's disease, slowdown of dementia development and some other brain-related diseases.

If you ever talked with senior citizens of the age about 60-70 who smoke (pipe or cigarettes even) - most of them have much more coherent though process and cognitive abilities are as sharp as they were in their 40s.
So no, smoking is not only dopamine provider.

And no, smoking doesn't cause 100% lung cancer. There are documented cases of long-living people - in particular - one woman who lived into 112, she was smoking up to 105, then, as she mentioned "cigarettes just stopped having any effect by then".

Its true that almost everyone is saying that you only live once but for me, I agree with you that since we only live once, we want ourselves to be at our healthiest state as we age. We only live once and people who smoke should consider that quitting will not only save themselves but also the people who would want to still see you doing what you love in your 80's and not in a wheelchair wearing an oxygen mask with an inhaler in one hand or not be able to speak. Think of your grandchildren people. It is selfish to say that you smoke because you'll die anyway. What we know for sure is that we only regret things we've done when it's too late. It's just sad because I lost my grandpa 2 years ago due to a lung cancer. He was completely aware that'll kill him but he continued it and only tried to stopped when it was too late for him or when he was unable to move his arm to reach a cigar due to extreme pain and weakness. I wished he would've seen me and my brother graduate at the same time. He would've been the happiest grandpa.  But he was late. And I miss him. Along with the hate I feel for him because he never tried quitting at least, I miss him. Smokers should realize that if they don't care for themselves anymore, think of the people who cares for you. You just need to be honest to yourself  that you're being addicted to it, lessen the use until you quit it, stay committed and live a better life with your family. We only live once. Quantity by years and quality by how healthy we are in the years to come. Don't miss out on your grand children's birthday and graduations because they would've wish that you should've quit smoking earlier and that you are still with them.

Last Spring it occurred to me this was the 40th year I have smoked. This thought occurred while I was in detox, fighting alcoholism. Been drinking just as long. Knew I had to quit drinking, figured I might as well quit smoking, too. Which do you think was harder?

Of COURSE quitting alcohol was way harder, I've had to totally rewire my very manner of thinking to get me off alcohol - but, the day to day, minute by minute, tiger constantly pawing at it's cage craving was for tobacco. I'd go to sleep each night happy and pleased I did not drink in the past 24 hours, but always felt cheated I had not had a cigarette.

After 6 months sober, and feeling fairly certain I will stay this way, I went out and bought a new car. Figure the $500/mo I used to spend on my addictions as a car payment plus insurance. Makes me proud of myself knowing I'm driving this nice car exactly because I quit drinking. Yet, I have to resist the urge of how cool it would be to smoke just one more cigarette.

I think AsapSCIENCE did a wonderful job of outlining the physical benefits of quitting smoking. Not only is stopping this debilitating habit good for your health, it is better for your overall happiness and peace of mind.

For those of you who are not yet convinced to stop smoking (which is hard to do facing the facts presented in this video) I hope to offer you an alternative way to think about the subject. Smoking is a choice, and like all choices, it can be made autonomously or non-autonomously (Autonomy = the ability to self-govern). The criteria for an autonomous choice include intentionally making the decision at hand, understanding of the decisions risks and benefits, and lack of control on the decision by external or internal forces other than your own. So is smoking an autonomous choice? It depends on the individual. If it is a minor who is choosing to smoke, with limited understanding of the long term repercussions discussed in this video, then it is not an autonomous choice, and should not be respected. However, an adult with clear understanding and intention to smoke may also not be making an autonomous choice due to controlling forces beyond their cognition.

But how is this possible? No one is forcing a cigarette into their hand or mouth, and they are not surrounded by second-hand smoke constantly. The controlling force in this situation is the addiction to the nicotine that is internally turning them to yet another cigarette. So how can we combat this urge to smoke with our own cognition?

The Split-Level Theory of Autonomy states that we can make decisions based on our preferences, that are of higher or lower level. For smokers, the lower level decision, also called the first-order desire, is to smoke cigarettes. On the other hand, the higher level decision, also called the second-order desire, is to live a healthier life and reap the benefits explained in this video. As we make more second-desire decisions, we live a more productive and positive life. Some argue, however, that as we make more first-desire decisions, we are reverting to the life of animals.

The bottom line is this: If you are a smoker and are choosing to do so on your own will, think about the risks of your choice and the potential long-lasting benefits of making your second, higher level choice. You will reap more than the physical benefits displayed in this video.

Actually, animal products (meat, dairy, and eggs) are probably the leading cause of preventable death...
Here are our top 15 killers (in America, very little difference in other developed countries such as the UK)
1) Heart disease
2) Cancer
3) Chronic lower respiratory diseases
4) Stroke
5) Unintentional injuries (accidents)
6) Alzheimer’s disease
7) Diabetes
8) Kidney disease
9) Flu and pneumonia
10) Intentional self harm (suicide)
11) Septicemia (blood poisoning)
12) Chronic liver disease and cirrhosis
13) Hypertension
14) Parkinson’s disease, and
15) Pneumonitis (inflammation of lung tissue)
Now here are is a list of diseases which the consumption of animal products increases the risk of:
1) Heart disease
2) Cancer
3) Chronic lower respiratory diseases
4) Stroke
6) Alzheimer’s disease
7) Diabetes
8) Kidney disease
9) Flu and pneumonia
10) Intentional self harm (suicide)
11) Septicemia (blood poisoning)
12) Chronic liver disease and cirrhosis
13) Hypertension
14) Parkinson’s disease, and
15) Pneumonitis (inflammation of lung tissue)
See the difference? Oh, only the accidents are not present.

And about smoking and heart disease... Eating an egg a day for 15 years increases your risk of a heart attack (heart/cardiovascular disease) the same as smoking 5 cigarettes a day for 15 years. 2 eggs a day? 10 cigarettes a day.
