This video makes no sense!! The symptoms are accurate but the timeline toward the beginning is just silly! How do you measure time after quitting? Is it time since you decided to quit or time since your last cigarette?? Cause smokers don't start going into withdraw every few hours without cigarettes. I mean sure some might but then the question is asked: who do some timelines apply to?? Some people smoke two packs a day. Some smoke only a couple times a week. I believe these effects but thats the kinda shit I want to know.

You should really have also addressed metabolism changes, which often lead to weight gain if you don't compensate. I didn't even consider that it could be an issue and I gained 2 stone in the first two months without changing my eating habits. I had to cut down what I ate a hell of a lot just to stabilise my weight and my doctor had a go at me for eating too little when I cut that down further to try to lose the weight. It certainly made it harder to quit. I'd never weighed more than 9 stone before and to feel and see my body changing on a weekly basis and feel like I'd lost all control was extremely hard when my normal solution to stress was smoking. Obviously, I don't think this should discourage people from quitting, but they should be aware of it. It's actually a great incentive to not start again, since I really don't want to go through that again. Certainly, since your metabolism starts slowing down around the age of 25, quitting before then would likely reduce those symptoms and if you're prepared for it, ensuring you maintain a healthy, active lifestyle and are careful about what you eat for the first few months should help reduce weight gain.

First day of Jan 2013, out of frustration that I was always out of breath, getting a monthly high fever and coughing out thick phlegm, I decided to quit cold turkey. I have been free of that bad habit for 4 years now. My hand and feet are not cold as ice anymore. They're also pink and healthy as blood now flows thru my body. It's true, I can taste food better now than before. My gums look black before but now it's all pink. i have had regular visit to my dentist in the last 4 years and my teeth look amazing since college days. And best part, I haven't had any more clogged up lungs and not anymore out of breath. I jog and exercise regularly to keep off all the pounds now that metabolism slows down. I'm thankful that finally the last time I tried quitting, I succeeded.

Kinda false info on nicotine being the main culprit for high blood pressure and heart rate and all the other negative things mentioned. It is mainly the tar, carbon monoxide, ddt and the countless other byproducts from combustible smoke and fire.

I switched to vaping (which still has nicotine; but none of the other byproducts of smoke.. like tar, carbon monoxide, ddt, etc ) and I've experienced ALL of the health benefits described in this video if you were to quit entirely.

My heart rate dropped drastically from 76bpm (as a smoker) to 52bpm (as a vaper), my lungs feel much much bigger, my touch sensitivity is better, my skin and face look healthier and less pale (better blood flow), my taste and smell improved very greatly, etc etc.

If you can't quit cigs..vaping is a great alternative.

The PG and VG in vape juice is actually very healthy, as it's a humectant and is anti-fungal and non-toxic.

I really liked this one, but you guys forgot to mention DNA Methylation by smoking, how it leaves a "footprint" in your genome and even decades after you stop smoking you are still at risk of cancer, pulmonary disease and strokes, because gene expression is "turned off" meaning you're at risk of genome mutation that can cause this diseases. Also, this gene expression is passed down to the smoker's kids, so their kids, even if the smoker hasn't smoked in years or even decades, are at greater risk of the same diseases the smoker's at risk off. Now, I'm not saying you shouldn't have kids with a smoker, but keep in mind that the risk is there. I understand epigenetics is not the topic of the video, but it is an effect that smoking has on the body.
